G.L. c. 209C.proposition: This Court has jurisdiction over this matter pursuant to G.L. c. 209C and G.L. c. 215, as this Complaint is for a modification of child custody and visitation, which were previously determined by this Court.

G.L. c. 215.proposition: This Court has jurisdiction over this matter pursuant to G.L. c. 209C and G.L. c. 215, as this Complaint is for a modification of child custody and visitation, which were previously determined by this Court.

G.L. c. 208, \u00a7 28.proposition: The current custody arrangement no longer serves the best interests of the minor child, contrary to the guiding principles of Massachusetts family law, as outlined in G.L. c. 208, § 28, and related case law.

Hunter v. Rose, 463 Mass. 488 (2012).proposition: The standard for modification of custody orders under Massachusetts law is whether there has been a material and substantial change in circumstances warranting a modification of the existing order and if such a modification is in the best interests of the child.
Hunter v. Rose, 463 Mass. 488 (2012).support_reasoning: The opinion discusses the general best-interests standard for initial custody determinations and factors a judge must weigh, but it does not address the standard for modification of an existing custody order. There is no language about a required ‘material and substantial change in circumstances’ as a prerequisite to modifying a prior custody judgment. Thus, the case does not provide authority for the specific Massachusetts standard for modification of custody orders stated in the proposition.
Hunter v. Rose, 463 Mass. 488 (2012).relevant_excerpt: “Parents have an equal right to custody of their children. … ‘In custody matters, the touchstone inquiry [is] … what is “best for the child” …. The determination of which parent will promote a child’s best interests rests within the discretion of the judge … [whose] findings … “must stand unless they are plainly wrong.” … However, the judge must weigh “all relevant factors in determining the best interests of the child.”’ (Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834, 840, 845 [2003]).”

Schechter v. Schechter, 88 Mass. App. Ct.raw_text: Schechter v. Schechter, 88 Mass. App. Ct. 239 (2015)
Schechter v. Schechter, 88 Mass. App. Ct.proposition: The standard for modification of custody orders under Massachusetts law is whether there has been a material and substantial change in circumstances warranting a modification of the existing order and if such a modification is in the best interests of the child.
Schechter v. Schechter, 88 Mass. App. Ct.support_reasoning: The opinion discusses custody determinations and removal, but not the standard for *modification* of existing custody orders. It frames the governing standard in terms of the child’s best interests and abuse presumptions, and for removal it interprets G.L. c. 208, § 30’s “upon cause shown” language, but nowhere articulates the ‘material and substantial change in circumstances’ requirement for modifying a prior custody judgment. Thus it does not provide authority for the specific modification standard stated in the proposition.
Schechter v. Schechter, 88 Mass. App. Ct.relevant_excerpt: “In Massachusetts the focus in a custody dispute between parents is not on their personal rights but on the welfare of the child. … [I]n deciding issues involving custody, the overriding concern of the court must be the promotion of the best interests of the children and their general welfare.” Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398, 402 (1981). … The statutory standard of ‘upon cause shown’ means that removal must be in the best interests of the child. Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas, 395 Mass. 704, 711 (1985).

Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas, 395 Mass. 7.proposition: In determining the best interests of the child, courts consider stability, the child's relationship with each parent, the fitness of each parent, and the preferences of older children capable of expressing a reasoned preference.
Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas, 395 Mass. 7.support_reasoning: The opinion discusses the best interests standard largely in the specific context of removal and focuses on factors such as improvement in the child’s quality of life, effect on relationship with the noncustodial parent, and the custodial parent’s reasons for relocation. It does not set out a general best-interests test including stability, parental fitness comparisons, or giving weight to the reasoned preferences of older children; in fact, it notes that young children’s preferences generally should not be given particular weight. Thus it does not support the broader, generalized proposition stated.
Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas, 395 Mass. 7.relevant_excerpt: “An evaluation of the best interests of the child requires attention to whether the quality of the child’s life may be improved by the change (including any improvement flowing from an improvement in the quality of the custodial parent’s life), the possible adverse effect of the elimination or curtailment of the child’s association with the noncustodial parent, and the extent to which moving or not moving will affect the emotional, physical, or developmental needs of the child. … [G]enerally such views of young children should not be given particular weight.”

Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834 (2003).proposition: In determining the best interests of the child, courts consider stability, the child's relationship with each parent, the fitness of each parent, and the preferences of older children capable of expressing a reasoned preference.
Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834 (2003).support_reasoning: The opinion discusses the best interests of the child and emphasizes factors such as stability of existing arrangements, continuity with the primary caregiver, each parent’s caretaking history, work schedules, attentiveness to medical and educational needs, and the child’s relationship with each parent. It does not, however, mention or apply any factor regarding an older child’s preference or a child’s expressed wishes as part of the analysis. Because a key component of the claimed proposition (consideration of older children’s reasoned preferences) is absent from this case, the citation does not fully support the proposition as stated.
Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834 (2003).relevant_excerpt: “If the parenting arrangement in which a child has lived is satisfactory and is reasonably capable of preservation, it is ordinarily in the child’s best interests to maintain that arrangement, and contrary to the child’s best interest to disrupt it. Stability is itself of enormous benefit to a child, and any unnecessary tampering with the status quo simply increases the risk of harm to the child.”

Mason v. Coleman, 447 Mass. 177 (2006).proposition: Courts have also recognized that the passage of time and the natural evolving needs of growing children may warrant modification of custody arrangements originally made when the children were much younger.
Mason v. Coleman, 447 Mass. 177 (2006).support_reasoning: The opinion concerns standards for relocation/removal under G.L. c. 208, § 30 in a joint physical custody context, not modification of custody based on the mere passage of time or evolving needs as children age. While the court discusses the children’s current developmental and educational circumstances, it does so within a static removal dispute, not as a basis to modify an earlier custody arrangement because the children have grown older. The case therefore does not establish or endorse the specific principle that the passage of time and natural evolving needs of growing children can warrant modification of custody arrangements made when they were younger.
Mason v. Coleman, 447 Mass. 177 (2006).relevant_excerpt: “‘[T]he best interests of the child standard is one grounded in the particular needs and circumstances of the individual child in question.’ Adoption of Vito, 431 Mass. 550, 566 (2000). Assuming the judge’s findings are not clearly erroneous, we review her determination of the best interests of the children only for an abuse of discretion.”

Rosenthal v. Maney, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 25.raw_text: Rosenthal v. Maney, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 257 (2001)
Rosenthal v. Maney, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 25.proposition: Courts have also recognized that the passage of time and the natural evolving needs of growing children may warrant modification of custody arrangements originally made when the children were much younger.
Rosenthal v. Maney, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 25.support_reasoning: The opinion deals with standards for modifying custody under a ‘material and substantial change in circumstances’ test and with relocation/removal, but it does not discuss the mere passage of time or the natural evolving needs of growing children as an independent basis for modification. Instead, it emphasizes that there was no material post‑divorce change warranting a shift of custody and that a temporary, court‑imposed change could not be used to justify a final modification. Nothing in the reasoning suggests that age-related developmental changes alone justified altering custody arrangements made when the child was younger.
Rosenthal v. Maney, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 25.relevant_excerpt: “A judgment modifying custody must be based on findings grounded in the evidence that, since the date of the prior custody order, there has been a change in circumstances ‘of sufficient magnitude to satisfy the governing principle by which the court must be guided in these cases, namely, whether the transfer of custody will be conducive to the welfare of the [child].’ Fuller v. Fuller, 2 Mass. App. Ct. 372, 376 (1974). ‘The uprooting of a child . . . should be done only for compelling reasons.’”

Pizzino v. Miller, 67 Mass. App. Ct. 865.raw_text: Pizzino v. Miller, 67 Mass. App. Ct. 865 (2006)
Pizzino v. Miller, 67 Mass. App. Ct. 865.proposition: Additional Massachusetts cases support the proposition that a parent with a substantially increased capacity to care for the child provides sufficient grounds for modification.
Pizzino v. Miller, 67 Mass. App. Ct. 865.support_reasoning: The opinion is a removal/relocation case under Yannas, not a general modification case about increased parental capacity. Although it acknowledges that the mother’s remarriage is a material and substantial post‑divorce change in circumstances under G.L. c. 208, § 28, the court does not state or apply any rule that an increased capacity to care for the child, by itself, is sufficient grounds for modification. The reasoning focuses on ‘real advantage’ and best interests in the relocation context, not on a broader modification standard tied to improved parenting capacity.
Pizzino v. Miller, 67 Mass. App. Ct. 865.relevant_excerpt: “Changed circumstances are those that occur subsequent to the judgment of divorce or subsequent to a prior modification. See Downey v. Downey, 55 Mass. App. Ct. 812, 815 (2002). In the present case, the mother’s marriage is plainly a material and substantial change in circumstances occurring subsequent to the date of divorce. The judge’s contrary treatment contributed to his devaluation of the mother’s marriage as a factor to be considered, and may well have had a significant effect on his over-all treatment of the case.”

Custody of Mary, 414 Mass. 317 (1993).proposition: Additional Massachusetts cases support the proposition that a parent with a substantially increased capacity to care for the child provides sufficient grounds for modification.
Custody of Mary, 414 Mass. 317 (1993).support_reasoning: The provided text is not Custody of Mary, 414 Mass. 317 (1993), but instead a criminal case involving a murder conviction, search and seizure issues, Miranda warnings, expert testimony, and sentencing. It does not concern child custody, parental fitness, or modification of custody orders, nor does it discuss a parent’s increased capacity to care for a child as grounds for modification. Therefore it cannot support the proposition about modification based on improved parental capacity.
Custody of Mary, 414 Mass. 317 (1993).relevant_excerpt: The opinion discusses warrantless search of a vehicle trunk, Miranda warnings, admissibility of expert testimony, and sentencing issues in a murder prosecution; there is no discussion of custody, parents, or child welfare, and thus no passage relevant to custody modification standards.
